comments:
Steps to reproduce:

I paste some text in an XML file.  
The file wasn't checked out. I'm using VSSPlugin.
I view with the text "Exception running validator code".  
Now I can't see the contents of the file.
I try to close the file reopen it, even with another type of views, but a view
showing this message is shown.
I exit Eclipse and launch it again, and everything is ok.

Please provide the log file (at <your workspace>\.metadata\.log). It might
contain  more information on the problem (a stracjk trace for the exception).

I suspect that message is not produced by any plugin in the Eclipse SDK.

Actually, the message comes from from the Resources plug-in, more specifically
Workspace#validateEdit. The reason validation failed should be in your log file.

Created an attachment (id=12999)
My log file

This is my log file.  I don't see anything meaningfull

You reported this against 2.1.2, but by looking at the log, it seems you are
running 3.0.
Can you confirm you are running Eclipse 3.0 instead of Eclipse 2.1.2?

Here is the entry corresponding to the message presented to the user. It shows
that VSSPlugin's FileModificationValidator.validateEdit failed due to an
assertion failure in jface.text.

Daniel, can you comment on this stack trace? I don't know in what situations one
could get into such an invalid state. If you want to see the full stack, search
the attached log for the first occurrence of "Workspace.validateEdit". Thanks.

!ENTRY org.eclipse.core.runtime 4 2 jul 05, 2004 11:11:26.58
!MESSAGE Problems occurred when invoking code from plug-in:
"org.eclipse.core.runtime".
!STACK 0

At that location the document partitioner checks that he only receives events
for his document. It seems that someone sends a
documentAboutToBeChanged(DocumentEvent e) with an event which is not for that
partitioner (wrong document). Looks like some listener registration went wrong
(either as a follow-up error or programming error in 3rd party plug-in).

Did you unzip 3.0 over existing 2.x? If so, anything can happen - this is not
supported.

I created a new workspace for Eclipse 3.0.

The only think I have done is to import into this workspace projects created
with Eclipse 2.1.

Is this ok?

The only strange think I did is to remove the Eclise3installdir/configuration
directory, because I reinstall a newer version of VisualEditor that had the same
internal version number.  This confused Eclipse. The VisualEditor team told me
to remove the configuration, I did it so, Eclipse rebuilt the configuration and
it worked ok again.

Daniel was asking about the install location (...\eclipse), not your workspace
location, which can be anywhere in your file system (you shouldn't have to
create a new workspace when upgrading Eclipse, just point the new version to
your existing workspace). Did you extract the Eclipse install zip to an empty
location, or on top of a location containing a previous version?

It seems your eclipse install root dir is not called "eclipse". Is that correct?
If so, beware that is not supported, and may cause you problems. 

Re: deleting the configuration area, that is ok - all data kept there can be
rebuilt if necessary.

Of course, I've installed Eclipse 3.0 to a new directory.

My root install dir is: E:\DAVID\des\Eclipse-3.0\

Unless we can reproduce it with a simple test case (without 3rd-party plug-ins),
or the problem is clearly understood to be in our side, we cannot investigate it.

If it still can be reproduced (is that the case?), please report the problem
against the provider of the VSSPlugin.

Closing (see comment 12 above). Please reopen if you can provide a test case not
involving 3rd party plug-ins.
